Published online: 03 March 2023. DOI: 10.1029\/2022JD037472","sensor":"MSU>Microwave Sounding Unit; AMSU-A->Advanced Microwave Sounding Unit-A, ATMS->Advanced Technology Microwave Sounder","source":"NOAA Fundamental Climate Data Record (FCDR) of MSU and AMSU-A Level 1c Brightness Temperature, Version 1.0; and NOAA ATMS Reprocessed SDR Products (RPATMSTDR), Version 2.0.  http:\/\/doi.org\/10.7289\/V51Z429F, http:\/\/doi:10.7289\/V5X63JT2, and https:\/\/www.avl.class.noaa.gov\/saa\/products\/search?datatype_family=RPATMSSDR","spatial_resolution":"2.5 latitude by 2.5 longitude","summary":"The Mean Layer Temperature \u2013 NOAA Climate Data Record (CDR) provides long-term temperature measurements for a thick layer of the upper atmosphere. Input data comes from Mean Layer Temperature (MLT) level-1c swath radiances taken by the Microwave Sounding Unit (MSU),and the Advanced Microwave Sounder Unit-A (AMSU-A) and the Advanced Technology Microwave Sounder (ATMS) aboard NOAA, NASA, and EUMETSAT satellites. The CDR was calibrated using the NOAA STAR Integrated Microwave Inter-Calibration Approach (IMICA) to remove calibration drifting errors. The final dataset incorporates inter-satellite bias corrections to ensure consistency, and adjustments that account for diurnal drift effect, differences between viewing angles, and channel frequency differences between sensors. The final record is a monthly global gridded dataset with 2.5\u00b0x2.5\u00b0 Latitude\/Longituderesolution, and extends from 1978\u2013present.","time_coverage_duration":"P562M","time_coverage_end":"2025-09-30 23:59:59Z","time_coverage_resolution":"P1M","time_coverage_start":"1978-12-01 00:00:00Z","title":"NOAA Climate Data Record (CDR) for Mean Layer Temperature, Version 5: Lower-Stratospher (TLS)","uncertainty_estimate":"0.04 K\/decade"}
